title: How to Steam Frozen Vegetables

methods.name: Using a Steaming Basket or Colander

steps.headline: Defrost frozen veggies in a refrigerator to remove excess water.
steps.description: If the recipe you’re making calls for a specific amount of water, you may want to thaw your veggies before steaming. The water locked inside frozen vegetables can add a considerable amount after it thaws. Defrosting veggies in your refrigerator will decrease the risk of bacteria contaminating your food. Use a bowl to catch the water during the thawing process. The time it takes food to thaw in your refrigerator will vary. Generally, you can expect 5 pounds (2.3 kg) of food to thaw in about 24 hours.

steps.headline: Boil a small amount of water in a pot.
steps.description: You only need about 2 to 3 inches (5.1 to 7.6 cm) of water in the bottom of the pot to steam your veggies. Bring the water to a boil on your stove, then place your steaming basket or colander in the pot so it hangs above the water. Your steaming basket or colander shouldn’t hang low enough to touch the water when boiling. About 1 to 2 inches (2.5 to 5.1 cm) of space should be sufficient.

steps.headline: Hang the veggies in the pot with a steaming basket or colander.
steps.description: Put the frozen veggies into a steaming basket or colander, nest the basket or colander in the pot, then put on the lid. Lids with a small vent are preferred, as these will allow a small amount of steam to escape, preventing condensation around the lid's edges. Water that drips from the edges of ventless lids can dirty your stovetop. Clean any spillage from your stovetop right away after steaming to prevent it from turning into a hard film.

steps.headline: Steam the veggies until they are fully cooked.
steps.description: The time it takes to steam your vegetables will vary. Veggies like zucchini or sweet peppers will likely only need 2 to 4 minutes, but root vegetables (like potatoes) may need 12 minutes or more. If you’re unsure whether your veggies are fully cooked, stick them with a fork. If you encounter resistance or hardness, especially at the center, you need to keep steaming.

steps.headline: Season the steamed veggies and enjoy.
steps.description: Once steamed, you can season the veggies as you see fit. Most veggies pair well with salt, pepper, and a little butter. You can get a sweet and spicy taste with a light dusting of chili flakes, some drizzled honey, and a little lemon juice. Seasonings should be adjusted according to taste. To prevent over-seasoning, add seasoning to the veggies little by little and check the flavor after each addition.

methods.name: Making Steamed Veggies in a Microwave

steps.headline: Add the veggies and a half tbsp (7.4 ml) of water to a microwave safe dish.
steps.description: Measure out a half tbsp of water and add it to your dish, then put in the veggies. Fasten a lid on top, then put the dish into the microwave. You may want to leave a small gap in the lid or use a lid with a small vent. In some cases, steam may build up in the container and cause damage. When cooking a lot of veggies, use enough water to coat the bottom of the dish in a thin layer of water. If you want the veggies to cook quickly, thaw them first in your refrigerator over night.

steps.headline: Heat the veggies in 1-minute increments until cooked through.
steps.description: Cooking in short increments is best, as overcooking can result in mushy veggies. Check to see whether they are cooked through after heating them each time. Flip the veggies with a spatula after each minute interval. Be careful when removing the lid to check the veggies after heating; steam from the water can cause burns.

steps.headline: Check if the veggies are finished cooking with a fork.
steps.description: Poke the veggies through the middle with a fork. If you don't encounter unnatural hardness or resistance, they’re ready to be removed from the microwave.

steps.headline: Remove and serve the veggies.
steps.description: Most vegetables will be ready in roughly 2 to 6 minutes. Low-power or older models of microwave may take longer than others. When veggies are fork tender, remove them from the microwave and enjoy.

steps.headline: Steam trimmed or split broccoli for 5 to 12 minutes.
steps.description: Stalks that have been only been trimmed will take about 8 to 12 minutes to steam. Broccoli that’s been split or is in florets will cook in roughly 5 to 7 minutes. Once steamed, you can season and serve. Try adding some flavor to your steamed broccoli with olive/pumpkin seed oil, lemon/lime juice, or a balsamic vinegar.

steps.headline: Prepare steamed cabbage or beans in 10 minutes flat.
steps.description: Cabbage that’s been cut into wedges and most kinds of beans will steam in 6 to 10 minutes. Lemon or lime juice work well for flavoring cabbage; garlic and salt are a great complementary flavor for beans.

steps.headline: Choose asparagus or kale when time is of the essence.
steps.description: These two vegetables steam a lot faster than other kinds. Asparagus cut into pieces that are 2 inches (5.1 cm) long and trimmed kale will be ready to eat in 4 to 7 minutes. When steamed, sprinkle the asparagus with olive oil, lemon zest, and sesame seeds for a healthy, flavorful treat. Kale works well with a light drizzling of olive oil and some crushed garlic or a dusting of garlic powder.

steps.headline: Cook cut or baby carrots in 7 to 12 minutes time.
steps.description: Cut carrots so that each piece is about a quarter-inch (.64-cm) thick and steam them for 7 to 10 minutes. Whole baby carrots will take a little longer; cook these for 10 to 12 minutes. The sweet flavors in carrots go nicely with honey and cinnamon or ginger. Mix the dish well after adding these ingredients to coat the carrots.
